ossj.common
Class AttributeAccessImpl

java.lang.Object
  ossj.common.AttributeAccessImpl
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable, javax.oss.AttributeAccess
Direct Known Subclasses:
EventImpl, ManagedEntityValueImpl, NamedQueryValueImpl, UpdateProcedureValueImpl
public abstract class AttributeAccessImpl
extends java.lang.Object
implements javax.oss.AttributeAccess

This is an implementation of the AttributeAccess. This Implementation handle the dirty marker as noted in the AttributeAccess definition:
The dirty marker of an attribute determine is the attribute is clean or not. For Example, an attribute that has been written by the application, but the change have not been replicated into the persistent representation of this attribute. This "dirty" information will be mainly used by the implementation/application.

For example: ServiceValue myService = serviceSession.getServiceValue(myServiceKey); // All Populated attributes of myService will not be "dirty". myService.setMandatory(true); // "mandatory" attribute is now tag "dirty" serviceSession.setService(myService); // When the client is calling the setService method, // the session knows, that only the "mandatory" attribute has been changed, // and nothing else. *

Since:
March 2005
Version:
1.1
Author:
OSS through Java Initiative, Vincent Perrot Sun Microsystems Inc.
See Also:

addAttributesTo

in this method, subclasses have to
  • call super.addAddtributesTo(attributeManager)
  • call attributeManager.addAttributes( ... ); with whatever attributes they want to add

configureAttributes

protected void configureAttributes(AttributeManager anAttributeManager)
in this method, subclasses can the type of the attributes, the added to the attribute manager in addAttributesTo(am). they can define them either as settable by calling attributeManager.setSettableAttributes( ... ) or optional attributes can be defined supported by calling attributeManager.setSupportedOptionalAttributes( ... )

isEnumerationBased

public boolean isEnumerationBased(java.lang.String attributeName)
                           throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
Returns true if the given attribute is in a format of an enumeration. If true is returned, then a call to attributeTypeFor() method will return the type of the class that contains the possible value definitions rather than the proper type of the handle value.

For exemple: 

 if
 (troubleTicketValue.isEnumerationBased("troubleTicketState")){
 System.out.println("tt state type is
 "+troubeTicketValue.attributeTypeFor("troubleTicketState")); // displays
 javax.oss.cbe.trouble.TroubleTicketState instead of java.lang.String

Specified by:
isEnumerationBased in interface javax.oss.AttributeAccess
Parameters:
attributeName - the name of the attribute to check
Returns:
true if the attribute is an enumeration type, false otherwise.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - the attribute name is null or is not recognized, or the value is bad

the - list of types

attributeTypeFor

public java.lang.String[] attributeTypeFor(java.lang.String attributeName)
                                    throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
Returns the array of supported types of the given attribute name, or null if the attribute name is unknown. If the attribute is an enumeration based attribute like:
  • *State
  • *Status
  • etc
this method shall return the type of the definition instead of int or String. If (isEnumerationBased) return String[0] = enumeration type
If (attribute name registered using addAttributeTypes()) return the String[] of recorded attribute types
else return String[1] = ((Method)getMethods.get(attributeName)).getReturnType().getName()

Specified by:
attributeTypeFor in interface javax.oss.AttributeAccess
Parameters:
attributeName - name of the attribute
Returns:
the array of supported types of the given attribute name
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - (the attribute name is null or is not recognized, or the value is bad)

make

public java.lang.Object make(java.lang.String typeName)
                      throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
Generic factory method for supported types.

This method try to first find a factory method:
if the typeName ends with "Impl", the Impl is cut)
make()
or
make(typeName)
if it fails the
Class.forName(typeName).newInstance();

Specified by:
make in interface javax.oss.AttributeAccess
Parameters:
typeName - the type of the object to be created
Returns:
the new created instance of the given type or null
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - (the attribute name is not recognized, or the value is bad)

getPopulatedAttributeNames

public java.lang.String[] getPopulatedAttributeNames()
Gets all attribute names, which attribute values contain something meaningful.

Although an attribute is populated, it can be null!

Specified by:
getPopulatedAttributeNames in interface javax.oss.AttributeAccess
Returns:
all names of attributes, which contain some data. When no attributes are populated an empty array is returned. It is required to return a subset of the array returned by getAttributeNames().

getAttributeNames

public java.lang.String[] getAttributeNames()
Returns all attribute names, which are available in this value object.

Use one of the returned names to access the generic methods getAttributeValue(...) and setAttributeValue(...).

This method may be used by generic clients to obtain information on the attributes. It does not say anything about the state of an attribute, i.e. if it is populated or not.

Specified by:
getAttributeNames in interface javax.oss.AttributeAccess
Returns:
the array contains all attribute names in no particular order.

public java.lang.String[] getSupportedOptionalAttributeNames()
Provide run-time support for the discovery of optional attributes support.

Specified by:
getSupportedOptionalAttributeNames in interface javax.oss.AttributeAccess
Returns:
The names of the optional attributes supported by an application.

setAttributeValue

public void setAttributeValue(java.lang.String attributeName,
                              java.lang.Object newValue)
                       throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
Assings a new value to an attribute.

Even though some attributes may be readonly in the server implementation, they can be set here nontheless. This is because value objects are also used as templates for a "query by template". To see which attributes can be set in the server implementation, the client needs to call getSettableAttributeNames()

Specified by:
setAttributeValue in interface javax.oss.AttributeAccess
Parameters:
attributeName - The attribute's name which shall be changed
Value - The attribute's new value. This can either be:
  • An Object which can be casted to the real type of attributesName
  • A wrapper class for primitive types, i.e. Integer instead of int. In any other case an exception is thrown.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - This Exception is thrown, when either
  • There is no attribute with this name
  • The value is out-of-range.

clone

public java.lang.Object clone()
Returns a deep copy of this value Subclasses of ManagedEntity should call this method first, which calls Object.clone() itself to create a shallow copy first, and then hande all properties which have to be deeply cloned.
